I haven't cried more at a movie this year, though I felt stupid for doing so.

This shaky cam melodrama, this soap opera for sophisticates, is implicitly critical of its country... yet it wasn't smuggled out of the country in a USB drive--it's Iran's official submission for the best foreign film Oscar!

The sharks...become class avengers, dishing out comeuppance to those enjoying the fruits of privilege; or, they're the embodiment of redneck madness, picking off disenfranchised peoples and the white males who would protect them.

The defense department comes off as sinister voyeurs, sending good men on a dangerous mission just to see what happens--and then refusing to intervene when it goes awry. It's like they're the audience at a horror movie or something.
It's hard not to feel like you could skip this movie and instead spend 75 minutes ambling through any urban space with an open mind and an eager eye. But maybe that's the point...
Like Gremlins without a single wink or smile.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Things are not as mumblecore as they seem.
Th[e result of a] carefully controlled strategy, tailor-made for boys who'll be thrilled into buying new things by the copious gore and bare breasts without being bored by things like even pacing.
Doesn't send up action-movie cliches--it embraces them, then just crowds them with labored one-liners.
[It's] not ultimately about God, the fall from grace, or Reaganism-it's just the personal tragedy of one man nostalgic for a youth he can't reclaim.
The apotheosis of this award season's escapism trend.
Herzog is so fascinated by the past because he looks at it and sees himself.
Southbys its Sundanceness, Texifies its Utah-grown clichés.
A real tragedy of animal exploitation.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Basically about the redemptive power of violence.
Like Tony Montana elevated to emir, suggesting that to idealize crime lords is to celebrate tyrants.
For a movie that adopts such a historical aesthetic, it also seems to hate history.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are two female characters, and both are villains for their sexuality.
Fun horror fantasy [that] feels like a blockbuster despite its indie budget.
Ignoring a potential subtext about the schizophrenic condition of women in 1960s America as they struggled to reconcile diverse roles, The Ward is defiantly mediocre.
A rapturous ode to Georgia and a plaint for paradise lost.
The apotheosis of our germophobic age of hand sanitizer.

"Tearjerker" would be the wrong word because of its pejorative implication. Restless earns your tears, eschewing in favor of charisma the emotional manipulation that typically mars movies about death-disrupted puppy love.
Crams a psychedelic, transcendental happening into the confines of narrative-documentary cliche, translating the lyrical into the prosaic.
Expertly balances its artful accruals of tension with its copious T&A and adolescent bonhomie.
Monarchy-boosting...this is how democracy dies.
A sci-fi comedy of cuckolding, a cynical and screwball study of love and suspicion.
Structurally, as tricky and sophisticated as The Social Network...[but] Eastwood's grasp of gayness is sometimes unduly flamboyant.
A sad, simple, effective glance at a relationship that, more substantially, explores the blurred distinctions between life and art.

Vampire stories are usually centered on women, serving as allegories for the alluring threat of sexual desire. But...this is a story about boys and men, about growing up and struggling with different models of masculinity.
Reviewers have noted that for all its sex, Shame isn't sexy. Really? Do they know Michael Fassbender's in it?
[The] relentless accumulation of details teases out the senseless barbarity of violence--whether it's committed by callous kids breaking the law or by a state acting within it.
Why would someone keep the camera running as he walks slowly up a staircase if he has to pay for VHS cassettes?
Less a love letter to cinema's origins than to its foundations: to light, legerdemain, and whirligigs.
The latent cultural rage that recently erupted in Occupy Wall Street protests has apparently been percolating within writer-director Andrew Niccol too.

As you'd expect...this is a movie about young people suffering through romantic problems. But they're young people whose relationships double as commentaries on the filmmaking process, by which Swanberg has apparently become disgusted.
Hard to defend but easy to adore.
A girl-power allegory, a cheeky genre-twister, and exploitation cinema par excellence...the kind of story Tarantino would adore.
A documentary about not making a movie.
Exceptionally well-made but emotionally distant debut offers a subjective view of contemporary culthood.
The twisty drama that unfolds in Ides is a microcosmic example of how meaningless political machinations have real effects on people's lives. As that old protest slogan went: Bush Lies, People Die.
Explores...the clash between our modern desire for [gender] equality and the vestiges of old-fashioned concepts about strong men and defenseless women.
Get it? It's a metaphor-for depression's volatile nature, its unpredictable effects, its inescapability, its enormity.
Exposes the caveperson in all of us.
West knows that the scariest thing you can see on screen isn't something bad happening to someone--it's something bad happening to someone you've grown to love over the last 100 minutes.
Lowbrow trash rewrit as highbrow treasure...the action movie treated like art, the cinematic equivalent of literary genre fiction...the purest cinema you'll see all year.
The smarties are going to relish Philadelphia Story a lot more than the two-bit trade...
A poignant story of the joys and sorrows, the humor and pathos of middle-class family life in wartime England.
This is the circus with more entertainment, more thrills, more spangles and as much Big Top atmosphere as RB-B&B itself can offer. It's a smash certainty for high-wire grosses.
Everywhere the camera looks there is something worth seeing.
Ultimate X smoothes out the rough edges of Evel [Kneivel]'s bad boy tradition and delivers a film that keeps mom and dad in on the cool -- Disney with a little flava.
In Fantasia 2000 a simple spell is rediscovered: elegant storytelling, masterful animation and timeless music make movie magic.
For those willing to forgive the loose history and storytelling here, the rewards are 3-D views of Manhattan that blossom on the screen and occasionally stun.
Most of the performances are thoroughly enjoyable, but they are also a long way from delivering what the film promises.
[T]he film is very much like Shackleton's expedition - just when things look grim there always appears on the horizon a saving grace.
The film is ... not so much a satisfying story as it is a fun loving promise of things to come in the world of IMAX in 3-D.
The filmmakers give us what we always want when it comes to MJ: images of a man caught in the act of being superhuman.
It's not a real movie, it just acts as one on Imax screens.
This is the sort of documentary that will leave some shaking their heads in awe and wonder.
Thrilling special effect gimmicks lose their luster, and Haunted Castle makes no real effort at suspenseful or artful storytelling.
Dolphins seems intended for a youthful fieldtrip type audience, but skillful filmmaking sets it apart from the typical wildlife documentary.
The filmmakers know how to please the eye, but it is not always the prettiest pictures that tell the best story.
The film is mildly informative, but things only come alive when land lizards suddenly land in your lap and when red and blue footed boobies fly over the seats.
[W]hen it's all sewn together the final product is as unlovely as Frankenstein.
The film is one of those rare entertainments that really is for the whole family - or at least everybody with a taste for friendly fantasy.
movie_title: Cirque du Soleil: Journey of Man (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Who cares?
Taking IMAX (R) cameras into these living underworlds proves an always bold, but not always successful venture.
Mysteries of Egypt proves once again that the next best thing to experiencing the real thing is an Imax film.
There are things happening in your body right now that you will never see unless you see this film.
Adrenaline Rush balances a genuine thirst for fun against a need to deliver educational content.
[T]horoughly enjoyable.
movie_title: Lost Worlds: Life in the Balance (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Coral Reef Adventure is a heavyweight film that fights a good fight on behalf of the world's endangered reefs -- and it lets the pictures do the punching.
There is really no chance for the film to hit a slow spot or get bogged down in minutiae -- new animals and new images are always on the horizon.
Australia: Land Beyond Time is an enjoyable Big Movie primarily because Australia is a weirdly beautiful place.
The movie is one of the best examples of artful Large Format filmmaking you are likely to see anytime soon.
[T]oo broad, too general approach misses some good opportunities.
[T]his Big Movie finds a great deal of drama and beauty in the sport of free diving.
Majestic White Horses is the rare sort of Large Format film that makes a virtue of subtlety.
Ski to The Max certainly spotlights some of the most incredible ski, snowboard and paraglide stunts anywhere ever filmed or seen.
The story is built around a few terrific acrobatic stunts and hair raising fly-bys -- but everything leading up to and following these moneyshots is a silly afterthought.
[T]he film becomes a droning, professorial lecture.
Kingdom of the Tiger is a completely engrossing Big Movie and a cure for those suffering from fear of the docudrama form.
The film gets close to the chimps the same way Goodall did, with a serious minded patience, respect and affection.
Thankfully, Alaska is not a laundry list of spectacular animals -- but a tribute to one of nature's last purely wild landscapes.
The film is ... an impossibly lucky safari delivered with a soft touch of science and philosophy.
The story is meant to be simple and sweet, but a series of painful clichés send the film into a dramatic spiral and all charm is lost.
movie_title: Legend of Loch Lomond (Legend of the Loch) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This Big Movie leaves no doubt that Mount Kilimanjaro is a truly amazing place.
movie_title: Kilimanjaro: To The Roof of Africa (2002)

movie_review_blurb: [S]tagy and preposterous scenes outnumber the well crafted moments.
Boy Band Bashing has become a cruel and lame sport -- if you don't like your fish raw, don't go out for sushi.
Bear lovers will find plenty to like here, but little that has not been seen before in the myriad of Discovery Channel type bear documentaries.
The characters here are probed and thoroughly penetrated, not through psychoanalysis but through a crucible of human conflict, action, gesture and expressive facial tones.
movie_title: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre (1948)

movie_review_blurb: It is a hallucinating and horrifying story, depicted with great power and the extraordinary beauty of photography that Lang has led his admirers to expect.
To flesh out the story, an alligator also makes a cameo appearance.
The film's biggest problem is its over-reliance on familiar genre tropes - a succession of cheap jump scares releases the dramatic tension instead of adding to it.
Some effective scares, but this is haunted house horror by numbers.
Asking an audience to laugh for two hours at the delirium tremens of a man suffering from alcoholism is a grisly thing.
Gomorrha transcends its medium and evidences humanity at its most despicable, and rates as an unconventional and unmissable instant classic.
Adventureland is no Superbad. To Mottola's credit, though, it's obvious that the director is deliberately trying to avoid repeating the same formula.
Hamburg cleverly borrows the most cliched and vomiting-inducing scenes from your typical Hollywood romantic comedy and turns them upside down with hilarious results.
Considering the talent involved in Winged Creatures, it's a pity that the movie never manages to fly above your average Hallmark drama.
Woo has a knack for the spectacular, and Red Cliff is certainly something to behold.
Unfunny and a poor excuse for satire, Dance Flick follows in the poor tradition of appalling spoof films.
There's no way to take this movie seriously, and that's exactly what makes it so much fun.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Beautiful locations add texture to this heart-warming comedy that never fails to charm.
Playing up to music and disabled character clichés, the filmmakers seem to be Oscar fishing with this almost-there drama.
If you like your horror with a bit of B-goodness and nostalgia added for flavour, then The Wolfman is right up your alley.
Do not, let me repeat that, DO NOT, watch the new A Nightmare on Elm Street.
A stunning, heartfelt and tremendously entertaining third entry that lives up to the standards of one of the best movie franchises of all time.
Despite the formulaic script and cringe worthy moments, the performances from the leads and creation of the subculture are well executed by director Montiel.
The Girl with All the Gifts may be a zombie movie, but it's remarkably unencumbered by fidelity to the canon it cannibalizes.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Just look at that cast, all robust and visibly charged by the top quality material on the page.
Colombian director Ciro Guerra conjures the mesmeric tones of Conrad and Herzog in this time-jumping fable about a shaman guiding two white explorers in search of a rare plant, 31 years apart.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A flawed curio, then, but don't be surprised if the years grant it cult-classic status.

Your mind is encouraged to put its feet up while watching Cemetery of Splendour. If you can do that, there is an ambience here that you'll gradually warm to. For many, however, it may prove too hard a sell.
A so-so tale of liberation getting out of hand.
Chu's real coup here is that this follow-up to the 2013 hit is a better film, shorn as it is of the tiresome CGI and limp final twist that marred its predecessor.
Sturridge is a dark, obsessive anti-hero in the classic noir mould, while Fast's years as a video artist create a visual and sonic tapestry that arrests the senses.
Not quite fabulous, no, but admittedly better than expected.
Bell makes for a plucky foil and Peter Dinklage is dependably dotty as a rival captain of industry. If only there was just a bit more meat on The Boss's funny bone.

This Sundance winner is a great documentary raised to distinction by virtue of the fact that directors Josh Kriegman and Elyse Steinberg were already shooting a fly-on-the-wall doc on the man when the eruption took place.

The whacky humour is hilarious at times but it can begin to feel a little forced by the third act. Jensen does manage to concoct a nicely macabre tone out of the unsettling ether, with the loud crashes of farce tempering a much darker twistedness.
A film designed for those days when you can't be bothered using your brain.

What makes this a standout of the studio's already glittering catalogue is the strong root psychological motive of the central character, which could just have you reaching for the hankies by the end.
Avoid at all costs.

The film looks very beautiful, austere for sure but gorgeously staged and framed. The performances are very good but although it's not very long, it does lack some punch. One for fans of austere auteurs.
Such technical brilliance from Aardman Animations should be no surprise by this stage. What really hits you is the persistent level of charm and hilarity as it coasts along.
Billions of high-fives and "awesomes" clang about as the four snot-coloured pieces of computer coding jump around this insipid villain.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: All the obvious ingredients are plonked on the table of this adaptation of Jojo Moyes chick-lit bestseller. The result is the dramatic equivalent of an English crumpet drowning in sugary whipped cream.
An admitted fan of the game, Jones's latest is designed solely to please up-to-speed subscribers. The rest of us will be baffled by the CGI slugathon of orcs vs knights vs wizards.
For all Pare's toothy charms and Gleeson's good-natured bumbling, a tangible chemistry between them feels absent. More's the pity.
Shot in jazzy black and white by cinematographer Chris Seager, and thundering with taste and tempo, Andy Goddard's film just sings.
What's that noise? It's the Metafiction Police coming to arrest this over-ambitious, pompous jiggery-pokery.
One for Woody completists only and a dreadful disappointment after the triumph of Blue Jasmine.
It is rare to find a documentary as beautifully weighted or that lives and breathes with as much spirit as this secret history. Essential viewing.

Sex Tape is stymied from the get-go by its couch-potato approach to comedy writing and its apparent fondness for smut-fuelled, gender-stereotypical relationship flaps that would make even dating teenagers roll their eyes.
It's all highly measured and tasteful, a rare thing when cinema and sacred cows meet.
The point of this whole exercise, bar putting on show how ridiculously competitive men can be, is the hunger we all feel for validation in the eyes of our peers and wider society.
These fairytale flourishes, a superb soundtrack and a potent environmental message are the film's finer qualities and source of its undeniable charm.
Had it embraced its shlocky B-movie undertow more wholly, a cult classic could have been the result.
Undeniably charming in its own peculiar way.
Smart cinematography and Danny Elfman's score brew heady atmospherics but the finale unseats this tension as it shuffles to a halt. More sting in the tail would have been nice.

Cheap scares are refreshingly absent... It turns out they're not needed when you can drop temperatures effectively by way of precision ratchet clicks in tension, excellent sound design and chilling allegorical nods to the monsters within.
A mess.
The results are, for the most part, refreshingly sophisticated for a kaboom-heavy actioner starring Mark Wahlberg.
Butterfield is dimmed by such bright lights in the cast around him. Some CGI-heavy scenes in the finale are wearisome but the madcap register of calmer moments makes for enchanting fun.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A curio from the fringes of movieland, indeed, but interviews and archive clips remind you this was no game for Shin and Choi.
Sachs's less-is-more directing style does make for some stunning moments between Jake and Tony where the mood crackles with a low-wattage hum.
The scenery is the only respite from the all-thumbs filmmaking that features overwrought music, ghastly fade-outs and even a psychotropic interlude.
A highly effective film for those looking for a fluffy and funny girls night out.

Ross stirs up some fascinating discussions in this indie drama... This, Stéphane Fontaine's shimmering cinematography and a generally tight cast are to be commended. What ruins Captain Fantastic are its less than authentic dabbles with comedy.
Always an actor of huge vitality, Foster gives a career best while Pine shows he's far more than just a pretty face. The landscape belongs to Bridges, however.

For all its high-velocity fun and the charm of that cast, your gut tells you that Lin's formulaic contribution to Star Trek could be the perfect way to sign-off before the law of diminishing returns really kicks into gear.
We'd love to blame wretched millennials for sinking Timur Bekmambetov's ship but the fact is this Ben Hur is sorely lacking.
Morgan had the chance to do something interesting with its sound building blocks but instead settled for punch-ups and trite hijinx.
Huppert's turn will be listed at the end of the year as one of the finest by an actress.
Hill, sporting extra kilos and an annoying laugh, is superbly repulsive as the amoral swine out to line his pockets while Teller's character provides the flimsy moral compass.

Depending what decade you were born in, you will either find this feature-length mockumentary spin-off from a popular Saturday Night Live troop utterly, painfully hilarious or as comedically enterprising as filing one's tax returns.
At the epicentre of the superb cast is Adriana Ugarte in the role of the younger Julieta. It is in her that the film finds a striking, unshakable keystone.
[A] bold and brilliant debut that heralds a major new talent.

You wouldn't call it the most original piece of horror cinema but it is admirably inventive in those spaces between the obligatory generic tropes of shrill sound design, creaking hinges, and the inevitable descent into the basement.
Valley of Love is a rather effective mood-piece, albeit with some overcooked attempts to pad out the dramatic space.
Such sources and archive footage (much taken by Bergman on her trusty 16mm) lend this portrait valuable authenticity.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Pete's Dragon won't be winning any awards for originality, but who cares when it does the simple things so effectively?
Up For Love is an exercise in formulaic charm whereby every gentle bend in the narrative road can be seen from a mile off and enough cute chuckles are stirred up on the path to eventual redemption.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fine, but really ought to have been better.

Mathieu Amalric and partner Stéphanie Cléau make a potent team both behind and in front of the camera in this steamy French noir that manages to get its dark thrills wrapped up in a trim and tidy 76 minutes.
Frankly, your children deserve better.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It is heated where it needs to be and Winocour, co-writing here with Jean-Stéphane Bron, delights in lobbing grenades into the Vincent-Jessie dynamic. Shame it fizzles out so abruptly.
High on charm, spirit, excitement and live-animal magic, Stuart McDonald's real-life tale is a breath of fresh air in a world of gloopy, sterile CGI mulch.
With an airiness that recalls both Jarmusch and at-times the aforementioned Coens, Zellner tightrope-walks between whimsical and gravid.
Human Capital works hard to keep things ticking evenly in each chapter but doesn't quite manage it.
Shame then that it lets itself down with some iffy dialogue and a slightly anticlimactic ending.
The Riot Club slightly labours its point but does many of the simple things well.
Yet another fine documentary outing for 2014.
The slick CGI rendering of the apes and set pieces is the main event but it is at the sacrifice of the first film's subtlety and mystique.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A soundtrack of bubbling brass and some lively cinematography keep the fires of mischief lit. Daft and delightful.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Writers Mickle and Nick Damici have an annoying habit of killing the noir with comedic one-liners. Genre hopping is all well and good, provided the thread running between is unshakeable. Disappointing.
Its remit to deliver a cinema-sized slice of the sitcom for its bafflingly vast legions of fans.
Unlike The Wind That Shakes The Barley, Loach's trademarks miss their targets.
Rolfe balances heart and edge very well while making great use of a fine soundtrack.
The centrifugal force is supplied by two stunning lead turns by Babluani and Bokeria.

Just as the chill of winter makes its acquaintance with us, Zvyagintsev hits us with the feel-bad hit of the year, 140-minutes of wide-angled dramatic rumination on the functional rot at the core of Russian society.
Steer well clear.
Albertine and Gillick are superb for untrained actors in a distinctly naturalist-style drama. Hogg, however, is the real star of the show.
What begins as quite a sophisticated outing -- some interesting relationship politics and decent physical comedy turns by Mann -- goes downhill after an hour.
What we have is a 90-minute mood piece, then, which is all well and good. But 90 minutes is still a long time to be caught in a depressive undertow.
It's a big load of much-ado-about-nothing dressed up in writer- director Sebastian Silva's arty movements.
It doesn't need to strut about waiting for a climax as 300 did, and punctuates its set pieces with stage-setting intrigues that keep it motoring.
Character-driven via a great ensemble cast, the humour is nuanced and unforced, while Butler's dialogue bobs and weaves deftly.
Gratuitousness (some scenes are simply porn) overshadows the crux of the tale, namely Franck's libido taking precedence over his conscience and the risk that he may become an accomplice.
Trust director Jim Jarmusch to sit back and wait for every permutation of the vampire film to come and go before casually serving up his own vision and leaving something properly iconic behind.
We see an athlete for whom winning came before any sense of sportsmanship, catalysed by a cognitive dissonance that saw him come to believe his own lies.
Leto almost steals the show, while Jennifer Garner represents stability as the gutsy hospital medic in a film from director Jean-Marc Vallee that is well-paced, involving and thought-provoking.
[A] limp slog that seeks to combine the glitz of reality dance contests with zero-to-hero rom-comedy.
Witty, tender and arrestingly gorgeous, Her is a masterpiece. Phoenix's central performance is of the lofty levels we have come to expect of him while Johansson disarms with only her voice.
The human characters all look flat and dead-eyed.
Concussion outwardly appears to be a sports drama about brain injury but it is actually a hagiography of Dr Omalu, and this weakens it.
[Director Tobias Lindholm's] cool Scandinavian temperament is at work again in A War, a taut drama that feels genetically linked to A Hijacking, and not just in the understatement of its title.
For all his flexing, Hoult is ultimately insubstantial and unconvincing as a homicidal drug hoover and Machiavellian scourge.
Low-down dirty fun.
An unassuming, soft-centred delight.

Everything -- the pace, the action, McGregor's frowning -- is fine. But you start to wonder if an institution like le Carré perhaps deserves a bit more care and reverence when his works are earmarked for filming.
Naturally, the nightmare gets out of hand by the finale and the body-count is high, but getting there is devilish fun.
Streep masterfully evokes the heiress's core dynamic - buffoonery mixed with a faint air of the tragic.
It is full of Malick's trademark flourishes and it dazzles in places. But two hours of "Malick does midlife crisis" is hard work.

[The film] keeps its taste levels deep in the gutter, for sure, but if you are not too prudish and don't mind a bit of low-down dirty fun, then there is just about enough here to drag it over the line. Just.
While some of these sledgehammers are tangible, most are figurative ones wielded by Vallee to push the film's "rip it up and start again" symbolism. The point is laboured, to say the least.
Apples Of The Golan opens up into the type of thought-provoking polemic that cinema can be excellent for.
That many of the flashbacks feature Huppert, a powerhouse of European cinema, is one of this pretentious and clumsy film's small mercies.

Unsurprisingly, there is ample philosophical and political meat to Eye In The Sky. As a crisis drama it also scores highly, rotating from one set to the next and linking the tense energies and tones of a superb cast.
Not a huge amount happens yet it is transfixing at times, largely a product of superbly moulded characters, gentle humour, refined performances and a charming devotion to human warmth.
Insubstantial but fun.

The visual flair cannot hide the many problems. Between the swashbuckling, there is Hemsworth's and Chastain's distracting Scottish accents, their characters' clumsily-penned love story and issues with continuity and plain narrative logic.
Costa excels under what must have been a demanding shoot.
Rarely does a drama balance a range of colours - intrigue, repulsion, beauty, dread, humour - with such brazen confidence.

Instead of dulling the drama, this almost journalistic approach to the narrative makes things tick with increasing urgency as the enormity of the system's ills and their impact on the ground are made clear.

At 76, the New Jersey native is able to laugh at himself and his missteps (Mission To Mars, Obsession) while speaking candidly and squarely about the times he got it right (take your pick from any of Scarface, Carrie, The Untouchables, Carlito's Way).
Humourless tosh.
A classic, and yet another durable blossom in Irish cinema's current purple patch.
Trachtenberg's outing is taut, slippery and tremendous value for money. Winstead is all doe-eyed grit right up to and beyond the film's final detonations.
The cast is an impressive ensemble, but Spotlight's genius is in its calmly urgent take on events. In doing so, it makes them all the more sobering and gravid.
Miller now ranks alongside Gilliam, Lynch, Burton et al as one of cinema's more distinct visionaries thanks to this elseworld of warped, hideous survivors and bizarre contraptions.
Humour and heart are prominent amid the breathtaking action.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's much to take from Anomalisa that belies its soft-eyed dolls and dry wit, not least its meticulous mix of the whacky with hard, uncompromising realism.
It has the feel of a handsome classroom study aid, but nonetheless one every child (from nine to 90) could learn from.
The two leads interlock seamlessly and make for a uniquely unnerving 'odd couple' in a film that is all the more spellbinding for the distance it keeps from us.

While it may lack the incisive scrutiny of, say, The Act of Killing, there is little sense to really be made of what Chubbuck did. And so if this at times feels like a well-made film-school project, perhaps that is as good a eulogy as any.
The most resounding take-away from the experience is an easy charm carried through by the human chemistry in the foreground.
Unoriginal as it is, part of you does envision a use for ...The Joneses as fodder for days when the brain needs 100 minutes or so offline.
A cinema release perhaps without equal this year in terms of how shockingly dreadful it is.
Spectacle, for sure, seems to be the word of the day and Valerian does deliver on that front.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wry, tasteful, unforced and with a tangible sense of the era, this is a portrait of a mercurial rock icon's formative years that, fittingly, ploughs its own furrow.
Nanjiani and Kazan are joined by a darling supporting cast that includes Holly Hunter and Ray Romano. And yes, the ending will very much leave you with "all the feels", as the kids say today.
There is too much of sheer fascination to map out here but some strands are particularly astonishing.

The spasmodic, overheated animation alone will probably be catnip to younger audiences but Captain Underpants... also displays some very subversive comedy writing that exudes a level of mischief that at times would make even Pixar blush.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Amid such horror, the quiet bravery in the face of this great modern evil is extraordinary. Even calling oneself a "journalist" beside such selfless heroism feels laughable.
It's unlikely that this will be the only review to drop this pun, but the biggest feeling we are left with by this third Cars instalment is one of being down this road before.
The real bounty of Conor McDermottroe's film is its core cast -- all of whom beam with sparkle and vigour.
