Delightful, athletic stuff with some unusual -- but wonderful -- location shooting. New York never looked better.
A part hypnotic, part profound, part send-up meditation on our financially imploding time.
Thanks to McConaughey's oily power and Friedkin's unflinching purpose it's a compelling beast.
Everything Gilroy and crew concoct only serves to mock the excellence and passion with which Greengrass delivered his films.
No less lovely than former films, in many ways lovelier, but Brave is boutique Pixar: less ambitious, more succinct, excellence at a lower ebb.
An uneven mix of impressively executed, violent clichés about good ol' boys defending the American right to flout the law.
This simple tale of love, friendship and the sea lingers in the mind long after the final credits.
Deliciously cruel to children, Roeg remains true to Dahl's underlying sense of real horror.
Despite DiCaprio's prize performance, purists will fume, but even as lit-crashing razzle-dazzle entertainment Luhrmann's adaptation is a candelabrum too far.
One for the die hards. The saving grace here is a knowing sense of humour so lacking in its predecessor, For Your Eyes Only.
A beautiful, literate and romantic piece of cinema.
For sheer old-fashioned, childhood rekindling adventure you really can't go past it.
As unexpected as it is intelligent, thanks to virtuoso work from Spielberg and Kushner, Lincoln is landmark filmmaking, while Day-Lewis is so authentic he pulls off that stovepipe.
Hitchcock for dummies: brisk, jolly, well-played but oversimplified.
It's an adventure into the very concept of storytelling: magical, enthralling and thrilling as much as bewildering, pompous and potty. In other words, up in the clouds.
This is a glorious widescreen vision of a hot and bothered America, at once beautiful and lost. Yes, it has dated, but its pessimistic last gasp ("We blew it...") still carries a prescient sting.
Northern Exposure with Jason Bourne. Which is a backhanded way of saying this is far from the challenging movie it promised to be.
This was sweet and charming at the time but now it just lacks either the comedy or sophistication of kids' fantasy film that we've all become accustomed to.
For all it boasts in ingenious style, this genial American yarn lacks the delicious bile of Jenuet's early days.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What results is, at best, only a sparingly funny series of mistaken identities and some really distasteful hooker gags delivered by the shocked townsfolk.
A superbly mounted, powerfully performed, if slightly underfed Apes sequel. That Reeves is set to direct Untitled Of The Planet Of The Apes next is cause for much celebration.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: At times it feels as if five different films are going on at once, but Schumer's whip-smart delivery and no-holds perkiness keeps it all in place.
Inordinately strange and tiresomely glum, but in spots hideously funny.
For all its relevance and grandeur, Steve Jobs is ridiculously entertaining. You might say, user-friendly.
Unshowy to a fault, Hytner delivers a fine, moving comedy of English manners between a writer and his eccentric tenant, which slowly deepens into an exploration of human bonds.
So godlike is Spielberg's status that we often take his talents for granted. The strange, riveting mix of Bridge Of Spies is another sterling reminder that we shouldn't.
Ephron's tart, grown-up script examines the inevitably of love finding a way despite the fight put up by this famous pair of snappy New Yorkers.
"Black sheep" of the American dynasty, Guggenheim was vital to 20th century art and, aided by Vreeland's lively montages and la-de-dah experts, she is astonishingly forthcoming.
Easily, almost nonchalantly, best in franchise, Rogue Nation dispenses with the dead weight of realism or relevance for state-of-the-art thrill-making in a classical mould.
For all the special effects and half-starved A-listers, this is a sodden beast. Perhaps there's a reason that Melville only told half the story.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It was (and remains) irreducibly [Spielberg's] masterpiece.
Perfectly paced and beautifully directed with some simply superb acting.
The acting troupe are great fun: Lee looks fit, Headey is sweet enough in a narrow role, Cleese fine-tunes his predictable Fawlty bit and Elwes stiff-upper lips to excess.
Gyllenhaal continues his post-Nightcrawler upgrade with another vivid performance in the key of strange.
A flawed work held together by Alwyn's tender presence.
A haunting and moving tribute to the Australians who sacrificed their lives in WWI.
Given Arnold Schwarzenegger and director John McTiernan had declined to return, this sequel to their macho sci-fi rumble in the jungle is surprisingly good.
It's slight, but sweet.
Could be an oblique prequel to Downfall.
If director Chuck Workman maps a familiar rise and fall of rule-breaking brilliance it is vindicated by the great raconteur and in-depth praise from an impressive roster.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Less vibrant than the original, but equally thoughtful and funny.
While the seemingly endless car chase has many literal gear changes, Getaway as a film is a monotone experience.
An uneven debut from John Slattery that nonetheless shows flashes of flair and a jet-black sense of humour.
It's got Russell's trademark eccentricity (read: slight bonkers-ness) all over it, which you may take as a warning or a recommendation.
What begins as a thrilling pastiche of comic-book formula gets bogged down in its own scientific prattle - not that you ever stop adoring Johansson's magnificent heroine.
For all its chilled intelligence and topical ambition this is a bloodless adaptation, but worth seeing for Hoffman's deft and ghostly presence.
Weightless, but not without its enchantments, this is Woody Allen coasting. But where better to coast than the loveliest coast of all?
The Canadian horror maestro scrapes away the surface of Hollywood to discover a magnificently Cronenbergian outbreak of tortured families, reprehensible behaviour and extreme violence.
The drama holds the attention throughout, even if the script never quite crackles as it might.
A persuasive, warts-and-bolts depiction of warfare from the guts of a tank yoked to an overwrought, sub-Private Ryan account of innocence under fire - so a hit and a miss.
Shimmering with awards potential, Leigh's glorious picture is a hilarious, confounding, wholehearted and dazzlingly performed portrait of an artist as an ageing man.
A unqualified success that blends New York wit with timeless storytelling; a risky piece of filmaking that never feels so.
Jolie is working in broad strokes, which isn't a sin. There are worse inspirations than the majesty and imperilled masculinity of David Lean.
A thrilling Iraq war story that manages to both honour the necessities of heroism and ruminate on what heroism might cost a man.

The less you try to figure out Anderson's rambling, mesmerising mystery, the better. Just relax and let this beautiful, haunting, hilarious, chaotic, irritating and possibly profound tragicomedy wash over you.
Swords and silly special effects in this enjoyable adventure.
On one level a fascinating refraction of the Amanda Knox trial into an examination of perception, on another an increasingly trying hall of mirrors.
Imagine a movie where Tom Hardy is the point of calm. Max's re-enfranchisement is a triumph of barking-mad imagination, jaw-dropping action, crackpot humour, and acting in the face of a hurricane.
An entertaining effort from the Ealing studios that sadly hasn't proved as enduring as its peers.

Buffeted by a lack of suspense, threadbare characters, and a very poor script, the stunning visuals, gloopy madness, and sterling Fassbenderiness can't prevent Prometheus feeling like Alien's poor relation.
An unknown treasure of a fantasy film and well worth a look for fans of the genre.
Flawed but interesting piece of art in the form of an anti-Western.
A mix-tape of successes and failures, perhaps too light for its subject, but a silly, easy watch.
Maths boffins + twist of mystery - patchy ending = uneven thriller.
Camp, over-the-top and entirely unbelievable: in short, the best thing John Woo has made in years.
Here is a film alive in a way we've not perceived before: a breathtakingly new visual experience, a precision-choreographed action thriller, and a classically minded piece of American art.
The most literally exciting film you will see this year. Forget the off-putting banner of another Iraq movie - go, watch, marvel, endure and book in the palliative of a stiff drink afterwards.
Without recourse to frilly cuffs or a montage to A Flock Of Seagulls' greatest hit, it plays the '80s card for something heartfelt.
Another not very charming but harmless fusion of animation and good old real-life.
Despite all the confusion, it's a simple case of the script being too ambitious. It may emulate a man experiencing flashbacks, but it doesn't help the audience.
Genuinely original: a silly, hilarious and oddly profound adaptation for adult-sized children.
Sam Shepard illuminated the old West - or at least the South American parts - with creaky charisma. He unleashes a growly old timer to rival Rooster Cogburn or Will Munny.
Foxes with bows and arrows. What could be better than that?
Superb central performance in this original take on the art biopic.
Surprisingly successful adaptation.
Exceptionally well-rendered and emotive war drama.

The mood's too good-spirited, and in that there are great pleasures - not least the sound-of-mind thinking of three rockers putting paid to the tired cliché of burbling rock gods trapped in their own shadows.

In Reitman's care, still channelling the breezy, matter-of-fact perkiness of Juno, it is an emphatic statement that Hollywood can still make great movies; a celebration that stardom can be as thrilling a concept as 3-D or CG or mooncalf vampires.
Like Lansbury, the film has aged well and retains almost all of its magic.
Eastwood hits all the right notes in exactly the right order, but it's his least personal film for a while.
Dark thriller that does its best but ultimately doesn't completely convince.
Okay, it isn't the graphic novel, but Zack Snyder clearly gives a toss, creating a smart, stylish, decent adaptation, if low on accessibility for the non-convert.
Bond meets Star Wars in one of the series' sillier outings.
It can't quite muster an explosive third act to match previous jaunts, but Moore had got his feet under the table.
If No Country For Old Men was vintage port, Burn After Reading is a shot of tequila: eye watering and hard to swallow, but the after-effect is terrific.
Crichton is after a giggly quality as if it's being told as a pub yarn, soaked in exaggeration and acute trickery to defeat impossible hurdles, while never far from redoubtable moral lesson.
Wise (and Crichton) concoct the most absorbing, riveting take on science fiction tempered with science fact.
Genuinely gripping, Demi makes an awesome femme fatale.
For all the enthralling visuals and action, the film feels garbled.
For all its serious intent, Tykwer's 'relevant' thriller proves to be perilously naff.
A pleasing and pretty enough re-run, just that bit diminished.
Danny Boyle's finest since Trainspotting. In fact, it's the best British/Indian gameshow-based romance of the millennium.
Stirring stuff that works thrillingly as drama, and should make Sheen a star, even if it compromises on historical insight.
It's never quite as tight or fierce as the original screwballers, but is fizzy and loveable and always worth watching.
Comic perfection.
A placid, poignant, well-kept secret of a movie.
It's glossy, charming, silly, and far too self-aware to be at all thrilling.
A mighty actor, a smart play, a clunky adaptation.
A well-crafted, visceral piece of historical filmmaking.
Deliberately provocative, infuriatingly melodramatic, this is a film that begs not to be taken seriously, and requires a ready suspension of moral discernment for maximum enjoyment.
Definitely a Disney classic but misses out much of the darker side of J.M.Barrie's fantasy tale.
A shapeless comedy of little merit.
If you don't love Shawshank, chances are you're beyond redemption.
There is simply nothing like it out there: profound, idiosyncratic, complex, sincere and magical; a confirmation that cinema can aspire to art.
It's not for everyone, but if you don't mind the brain-bending confusion of the plot and occasional feeling of '80s high camp, this isn't as bad as its detractors would have it.
A hilarious comedy (although not a very believable one -- there can be no eight-year-olds this ingenious) that kids will love and adults won't mind sitting through either.
Time for death to call in sick?
There's no question it's stunningly mounted, and Wasikowska makes a much stronger Jane than Alice, but the romance is overripe and the climax underdone.
One of the best traditional thrillers to come down the pike in quite some time.
An absurd-sounding concept rendered wholly believable and thrilling by a fearless young actress and a director at the top of his game.
Action-packed, gorgeous, and faithfully whimsical: Hergé thought Spielberg the only director capable of filming Tintin. He was onto something.
More sprightly and less encumbered with the need to titillate that would ring-fence the Carry Ons in later life, there is a youthfulness about Spying that still remains fresher than the colour films.
Proof that, in the right hands, documentaries boast as much heart as any feature. This one got soul too. Wonderful.
A sequel confident in what it's about - bigger, better, funnier, without stretching the joke.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With so many films adapted from novels, it's nice to see cinema paying homage to unheralded greats of literature like Sebald.
Lavish pirate adventure that launched Errol Flynn onto 1930's screens and ensured that buckles would be swashed for a good few years to follow.
As smart and cautionary now as it was in the '70s.
The action is stilted and infrequent, reduced to indifferent gun play, car chases and one standout explosion when a gas main ignites.
This may have been made (and banned) in the 1930s, but it remains a neatly disturbing horror with a definitive ending.
Slightly underpowered as an espionage thriller, this is nonetheless a fascinating story told with real panache.
Light, assured, and utterly charming: Woody Allen's sublime gifts are still intact.
There's a heist, a jail break, and a flawless melding of comedy and drama and Steven Soderbergh ties it together like a master.
The film takes flight as a grand chase movie, and leaves its ambition in its wake.
This 12th of the franchise shows that the series could also tackle satire, as well as the tits and bum humour.
There is much to be impressed with here.
As when Coppola made The Rainmaker, perfectly adequate as it was, there's a sense that Polanski is comfortable plying his expertise: a decent professional job, untroubled by the virtues of art.
Its restraint might put off thrill-seekers, but if you can endure the wooden dialogue and sloppy exposition, it musters the entertainment quotient of a middle-order Harry Potter.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Hasn't aged very well.
Genuinely creepy, satirical and occasionally daft horror tales with a distinctly moral bent.
They make a fun duo, but none of the constituent genres work in this overbearing action-rom-com.
There's no doubting the energy, but without Colin Farrell's fervour, or any novel spin, it's no more than treading water from this gang.
Far from the catastrophe the US bewailed, but still disappointingly clunky.
Despite Cage in a snit, it's a likable if functional summer-show.
By turns fascinating and mysterious.
Manages to be both very silly and highly forgettable. Only for those who collect killer-children films.
The intention is Spain, the kids are Uruguay, but the direction and script are England.
Some days a runaway train movie just hits the spot.
Think the blazing joys of Chariots Of Fire where the race is to the end of a sentence. Can it be that the British are coming?
Enough large-scale spectacle scenes to outweigh the inevitable religiose sludge that creeps in between them.
Nine years on from the first movie but somehow the effects have gone backwards and the charm has gone missing.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Can't escape its fluffy, Disney-like premise of fulfilling dreams, with Spears merely portraying an extension of her real-life image: Not a novice, not yet a pro.
Onscreen, Bjork and her musicians simply can't hold us rapt through the many abstract, ponderous moments the way they could onstage.
The film understands that the most interesting thing about Nas is how he once converted 20 years of living into 40 minutes of art that transcends its genre, its era, even its medium.
Expertly paced and gorgeous to behold, Sam de Jong's Dutch-language directorial debut sets a stylish coming-of-age story in a bleak Amsterdam housing project.
In the particulars of a family quest film, viewers should see the universal. But in William Spicer and James Moore's documentary Mission to Lars, we instead get a whole lot of the specifics.
Grisly, deviously twisted and wince-inducing, Jigsaw plays like a greatest hits of the Saw series, blended up to if not a series high, then certainly a return to form.
Spider-Man: Homecoming's biggest achievement is that it makes you forget it's the third different Spider-Man - and second reboot - in less than 20 years.
Baby Driver is certainly an entertaining ride but when you pop the hood there's not much under its shiny surface.
What starts so promisingly quickly becomes so generic.
Salazar's Revenge quickly reminds you why we all fell in love with Depp's Captain Jack Sparrow and his drunken exploits in the first place.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What makes Lights Out so terrifyingly effective is that it takes full advantage of that primal fear of the dark that almost everybody has felt at some point in their lives. And this time, there really is something under your bed.
Sorcerer is a stunning reimagining of a masterpiece, one that crucially doesn't try to replicate what came before. Instead, it follows its own dangerous path.
The Cradle of Life ain't Shakespeare and it doesn't reinvent the action-adventure in any profound way. On the other hand, it's a sleek, well-produced popcorn picture.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Matchstick Men is a spiffy piece of entertainment crafted by a master filmmaker at the top of his game, and it features a group of perfectly cast actors.

The sequel essentially replays the events of the first film and relocates the whole shebang to Washington, D.C., and therein rests the comedy's near-fatal flaw. It's all remarkably predictable and too often downright silly.
Mike Myers' companion piece to fellow Canadian Jim Carrey's portrayal of the Grinch falls flat, goes splat and, quite honestly, ain't all that.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The best suicides-meet-in-purgatory-and-fall-in-love romantic comedy-drama ever made. It may also be the only suicides-meet-in-purgatory-and-fall-in-love romantic comedy-drama ever made.
All in all, Massacre is proud to be nothing more than it intends to be, namely a straightforward, non-moralizing and unrepentant horror flick.
Using home movies and other footage, Kopple provides a discomfiting portrait of a family's deep-seated dysfunction.
